Often derived from Proto-Indo-European *dÊ°er- (â€œto holdâ€),[1][2] but this root presents a number of problems, such as the lack of the suffix *-onos in Proto-Indo-European, the lack of any words meaning "chair" from this root in any other Indo-European languages, and the lack of any definite Greek descendants from the root itself,[3] therefore rendering comparisons to Î¸Ïá¾¶Î½Î¿Ï‚ (thrÃ¢nos, â€œbenchâ€) and Î¸Ïá¿†Î½Ï…Ï‚ (thrÃªnus, â€œfootstoolâ€) improbable. Due to the suffix -ÏŒÎ½Î¿Ï‚ usually being a indicative of a Pre-Greek word (as in Ï‡ÏÏŒÎ½Î¿Ï‚ (khrÃ³nos), ÎšÏÏŒÎ½Î¿Ï‚ (KrÃ³nos)), Beekes suggests that this could be the case for Î¸ÏÏŒÎ½Î¿Ï‚ (thrÃ³nos) as well.[4]
